facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 217 of 1956 is an appeal by special leave from the decision dated December 7, 1953, of the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India, Madras, in Misc. Case No. 111-C. 387 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 217 of 1956. Appeal by special leave from the decision date December 7, 1953, of the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India, Madras, in Misc. Case No. 111-C. 387 of 1953.

facts.text: Three appeals arise out of two industrial disputes Nos. 24 and 26 of 1951 between the appellants and their workmen.

anchor.surface_text: The following Judgment of the Court was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR J. These three appeals arise out of two industrial disputes Nos. 24 and 26 of 1951 between the appellants and their workmen.

facts.text: Dispute No. 24 of 1951 arose between the management and workers of the Sree Meenakshi Mills Ltd., Madurai.

anchor.surface_text: Dispute No. 24 of 1951 had arisen between the management and workers of the Sree Meenakshi Mills Ltd., Madurai, whereas dispute No. 26 of 1951, was between the management and workers of the Thiakesar Alai Manapparai.

facts.text: Dispute No. 26 of 1951 was between the management and workers of the Thiakesar Alai Manapparai.

anchor.surface_text: , whereas dispute No. 26 of 1951, was between the management and workers of the Thiakesar Alai Manapparai. Both the disputes were in respect of bonus claimed by the workmen for the year 1950-

facts.text: Both disputes were in respect of bonus claimed by the workmen for the year 1950-51.

anchor.surface_text: Both the disputes were in respect of bonus claimed by the workmen for the year 1950- The workmen claimed bonus for the year 1950-51 on the allegation that the two mills companystituted one unit

facts.text: Workmen claimed bonus for 1950-51 alleging the two mills constituted one unit and made profits.

anchor.surface_text: The workmen claimed bonus for the year 1950-51 on the allegation that the two mills companystituted one unit and had made profits during the relevant year.

facts.text: Appellants contended the two mills were two different units and there was a trading loss in the relevant year so no bonus payable.

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, the appellants companytended that the two mills were two different units and the claims for bonus made by the workmen against them should number be companysidered together. According to the appellants, during the relevant year there was a trading loss

facts.text: Industrial Tribunal rejected appellants' pleas and held the two mills formed part of the same unit.

anchor.surface_text: and as such numberbonus was payable to the workers. The Industrial Tribunal rejected the pleas raised by the appellants and held that the two mills formed part of the same unit.

facts.text: Industrial Tribunal found surplus of Rs. 2,87,676 for the year and awarded three months bonus to workmen.

anchor.surface_text: It also came to the companyclusion that for the year in question there was a surplus of Rs. 2,87,676 against which the workmens claim for bonus was justified. That is why the tribunal awarded three months bonus to the workmen.

facts.text: Appellants preferred appeals Nos. 133 and 134 of 1952 to Labour Appellate Tribunal, Madras.

anchor.surface_text: Against this decision the appellants preferred two appeals Nos. 133 and 134 of 1952 to the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India at Madras.

facts.text: Workmen preferred appeal No. 168 of 1952 claiming larger bonus.

anchor.surface_text: In these appeals the appellants challenged the findings made by the tribunal against them and urged that bonus was number payable during the relevant year. The workmen also preferred an appeal, No. 168 of 1952,

facts.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal confirmed that two mills formed part of the same unit.

anchor.surface_text: and in this appeal they claimed a larger bonus than what had been awarded by the tribunal below. The appellate tribunal companyfirmed the finding of the tribunal that the two mills formed part of the same unit.

facts.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal found net surplus available for bonus as Rs. 2,57,496.

anchor.surface_text: According to the appellate tribunal, the net surplus available for distribution as bonus came to Rs. 2,57,496.

facts.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal disallowed deductions including Rs. 4,43,927 of depreciation claim out of Rs. 8,43,927.

anchor.surface_text: The claim made by the appellants in respect of various deductions was examined by the appellate tribunal and deductions were substantially, disallowed in respect of three items. In respect of an amount of Rs. 8,43,927 claimed by the appellants as depreciation on machinery and buildings the appellate tribunal companycurred with the industrial tribunal in holding that the claim only for a sum of Rs. 4,00,000 was admissible in other words, a claim for deducting the balance of Rs. 4,43,927 was disallowed.

facts.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal agreed provision for taxation of Rs. 1,75,000 was adequate.

anchor.surface_text: It is this finding in particular with which we are directly companycerned in the present appeals. it may be pointed out at this stage that in determining the amount of net surplus available for distribution as bonus, the appellate tribunal agreed with the industrial tribunal that the provision for taxation made by the appellants to the extent of Rs. 1,75,000 was adequate.

facts.text: Appeals Nos. 133, 134 and 168 of 1952 were dismissed by Labour Appellate Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeals preferred by the appellants as well as the respondents failed and were dismissed by the appellate tribunal.

facts.text: Appellants preferred Civil Appeals Nos. 218 and 219 of 1956 by special leave against LAT order.

anchor.surface_text: Against the order dismissing their appeals, the appellants have preferred to this Court by special leave the present Civil Appeals Nos. 218 and 219 of 1956.

facts.text: Appellants filed review application Misc. Case No. III-C-387 of 1953 before LAT which was rejected.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants had also preferred an application for review before the Labour Appellate Tribunal, Misc. Case No. III-C- 387 of 1953  Review  on the ground that the order passed by the Labour Appellate Tribunal was patently erroneous inasmuch as there was a mistake apparent on the face of the record which should be companyrected under the appellate tribunals powers of review. The appellate tribunal hold that it had numberpower of review and that,- even if it bad such a power, numbercase had been made out for the exercise of such power because there was numbermistake apparent on the face of the record which companyld number have been discovered whet  the order was made in the presence of the parties.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 217 of 1956 is against LAT's refusal of review.

anchor.surface_text: Against this decision, the appellants have preferred to this Court by special leave the present Civil A peal No. 217 of 1956.

facts.text: Appellants debited depreciation of Rs. 8,43,927 on machinery and buildings.

facts.text: Workmen applied for inspection of accounts which was allowed by Industrial Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that, when the proceedings were pending before the industrial tribunal, an application was made by the workmen requesting the tribunal to direct the appellants to allow the workmen inspection of accounts. The Tribunal passed an order for inspection and inspection was allowed.

facts.text: Appellants failed to provide details of Rs. 8,44,000 depreciation claim despite promise.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon an application was made on behalf of the workmen on February 28, 1952, for particulars relating to the amount of Rs. 8,44,000 claimed by the appellants by way of depreciation. The appellants promised to supply the information on March 8, 1952 but ultimately, on behalf of the appellants, it was stated to the tribunal that the appellants were number able to give the details called for.

facts.text: Both tribunals commented adversely on appellants' failure to supply depreciation particulars.

anchor.surface_text: The industrial tribunal and the appellate tribunal have both adversely companymented on this companyduct of the appellants and they were presumably disposed to draw an adverse inference against the appellants in respect of the amount of depreciation in question.

This principle has been recognized by what is often described as the Full Bench formula as laid down in the matter of The -Mill Owners Association, Bombay v. The Rashtriya Mill Mazdoor Sangh, Bombay  1 . According to this formula, distributable surplus has to be ascertained after providing from the gross profits for  1  depreciation,  2  rehabilitation,  3  return at 6 on the paid-up capital,  4  return on the working capital at a lesser but reasonable rate, and  5  for an estimated amount in respect of the payment of income-tax.

concepts.interpretation: Distributable surplus ascertained after providing for depreciation (normal only), rehabilitation, return on capital, return on working capital, and provision for income-tax; initial and additional depreciation not allowed as prior charges.

anchor.surface_text: The true nature and character of the workmens claim for bonus against their employers is number well settled. Bonus is number, as its etymological meaning would suggest, a mere matter of bounty gratuitously made by the employer to his employees number is it a matter of deferred wages. It has been held by this Court in Muir Mills Co. Ltd. v. Suti Mills Mazdoor Union, Kanpur  1  that the term bonus is applied to a cash payment made in addition to wages.

arguments.court_reasoning: Bonus gross profits differ from taxable; exemptions apply

holdings.text: In determining the net surplus available for distribution as bonus, it is not obligatory on industrial tribunals to allow the whole of the depreciation admissible under the provisions of the Income-tax Act; only normal depreciation (including multiple shift depreciation) ranks as a prior charge under the Full Bench formula, but not initial or additional depreciation.

anchor.surface_text: That is why, in the result, this subsequent Full Bench held that only normal depreciation including multiple shift depreciation, but not initial or additional depreciation, should rank as prior charge in applying the Full Bench formula as to the payment of bonus. If it cannot be disputed that in industrial adjudication it is not obligatory to adopt the very same procedure as prescribed by the Income-tax Act for ascertaining gross profits and then determining the amount of net surplus available, it is not easy to accept the appellants argument that in respect of depreciation alone industrial tribunals must necessarily and in every case follow the relevant provisions of the Income-tax Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Industrial adjudication follows Full Bench formula based on social justice and fair apportionment between labour and capital; not bound by Income-tax Act procedures; initial and additional depreciation are abnormal, time-limited tax concessions not ranking as prior charges to avoid depriving workmen of surplus.

holdings.text: The Code of Civil Procedure, including Order 47, applies to proceedings before the Labour Appellate Tribunal, which thus has jurisdiction to review its own orders in appropriate cases for mistake apparent on the face of the record.

anchor.surface_text: This Court has recently had occasion to consider the question about the applicability of the Code of Civil Procedure to the proceedings before the Labour Appellate Tribunal in Mills. Martin Burn Ltd. v. R. A. Banerjee Civil Appeal No. 92 of 1957. Section 91 and s. 10 of the Industrial Disputes Appellate Tribunal Act, 1950, as well as the relevant rules and orders framed under the Act were considered and it was held that the Code of Civil Procedure applies to the proceedings before the appellate tribunal with the result that the appellate tribunal can exercise its powers under O. 41, r. 21 as well as under s. 151 of the Code. It is true that in this case there was no occasion to consider the applicability of the provisions of O. 47 of the Code but that does not make any difference. If the Code of Civil Procedure applies to the proceedings before the Labour Appellate Tribunal, it is clear that the provisions of O. 47 would apply to these proceedings as much as s.151 of the Code or the provisions of O. 41. We must accordingly hold that the appellate tribunal erred in law in coming to the conclusion that it had no jurisdiction to review its own order under the provisions of O. 47 of the Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Extends Martin Burn Ltd. precedent holding CPC applies to LAT under ss.9(1) & 10 of ID(AT) Act; O.47 logically included as with O.41 r.21 and s.151.

holdings.text: There was no mistake apparent on the face of the record warranting review of the Labour Appellate Tribunal's order regarding adequacy of Rs.1,75,000 provision for taxation, despite disallowance of Rs.4,43,927 depreciation.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, satisfied that the grievance made by the appellants against the order passed by the appellate tribunal on the ground that it suffers from a mistake apparent on the face of the record is not well founded.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Gross profits for bonus calculation differ from taxable income under IT Act; initial/additional depreciation exempt from tax anyway; disallowance does not increase tax liability as employer gets exemptions; provision adequacy judged per IT Act, not bonus formula.

holdings.text: The appeals fail on merits; Labour Appellate Tribunal's disallowance of initial and additional depreciation claims upheld, confirming net surplus of Rs.2,57,496 available for bonus.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeals fail on the merits and must be dismissed with costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirms lower tribunals' application of Full Bench formula and findings on unit, surplus, and deductions; appellants' conduct in failing to provide depreciation details supports inference against full claim.

anchor.surface_text: This question has been decided by a Full Bench of the Labour Appellate Tribunal in U.P. Electric Supply Co. Ltd. v. Their Workmen  1 . It is true that the question of bonus had to be companysidered in this case in the light of the provisions of the U. P. Electricity  Supply  Act, 1948. Nevertheless the Full Bench has dealt with this matter on general companysiderations and has set at rest the divergence of views expressed by different Benches of the tribunal on this point.

precedents.case_name: Martin Burn Ltd. v. R. A. Banerjee
precedents.cited_proposition: Code of Civil Procedure applies to proceedings before Labour Appellate Tribunal

precedents.citation: Model Mills, etc. Textile Mills Nagpur v. Rashtriya Mill Mazdoor Sangh  1

anchor.surface_text: It would number be necessary to refer briefly to the decisions of industrial companyrts to which our attention has been drawn by the learned companynsel for the appellants. In Model Mills, etc. Textile Mills Nagpur v. Rashtriya Mill Mazdoor Sangh  1 , the implications of the Full Bench formula for ascertainment of bonus have been explained. It is observed that the formula did number purport to direct what a companycern should do or should number do with its own moneys.

precedents.case_name: Model Mills Textile Mills Nagpur v. Rashtriya Mill Mazdoor Sangh
precedents.cited_proposition: Full Bench formula equates rights of capital and labour; income-tax on trading profits deducted even if exemption granted due to past losses

precedents.citation: Mahalaxmi Wollen Mills Ltd. v. Their Work-Workmen 1

anchor.surface_text: The same view has been expressed by the appellate tribunal in Mahalaxmi Wollen Mills Ltd. v. Their Work-Workmen 1  In this case, it has been held that even if a companycern is allowed exemption from the levy of incometax because of prior losses or unabsorbed depreciation, etc., that by itself is numberground for preventing the companycern from claiming the amount of income- tax it would have been liable to pay if the profits made in the relevant year alone had been taken into account.

precedents.case_name: Mahalaxmi Woollen Mills Ltd. v. Their Workmen
precedents.cited_proposition: income-tax on relevant year profits deducted even if exemption due to prior losses

precedents.citation: Bennett Coleman and Company, Ltd. v. Their Workmen 2

anchor.surface_text: Similarly in Bennett Coleman and Company, Ltd. v. Their Workmen 2  the Labour Appellate Tribunal has held that unabsorbed depreciation and loss incurred during prior years are allowed under s. 24  2  of the Income-tax Act to be adjusted against the profits of a future year. Where the companypany claim,-, either to adjust this amount against gross profits or to deduct such amount of income-tax as would be payable on the profits if the said two items are number to be adjusted,

precedents.case_name: Bennett Coleman and Company Ltd. v. Their Workmen
precedents.cited_proposition: unabsorbed depreciation and prior losses adjusted; provision for tax on profits accordingly

precedents.citation: B. E. S. T. Workers Union v. Bombay Suburban Electric Supply Ltd.  1 , and Greaves Cotton and Crompton Parkinson, Ltd. v. Its Workmen  2

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Viswanatha Sastri has strongly relied on two labour decisions reported in B. E. S. T. Workers Union v. Bombay Suburban Electric Supply Ltd.  1 , and Greaves Cotton and Crompton Parkinson, Ltd. v. Its Workmen  2 . These two decisions numberdoubt support the appellants arguments before us but, for the reasons which we have already given, we must hold that these decisions are number sound or companyrect.

precedents.case_name: B.E.S.T. Workers Union v. Bombay Suburban Electric Supply Ltd.; Greaves Cotton and Crompton Parkinson Ltd. v. Its Workmen
precedents.cited_proposition: support appellants' arguments on income-tax provision

precedents.citation: Greaves Cotton and Crompton Parkinson, Ltd. v. Its Workmen  2

anchor.surface_text: and Greaves Cotton and Crompton Parkinson, Ltd. v. Its Workmen  2 . These two decisions numberdoubt support the appellants arguments before us but, for the reasons which we have already given, we must hold that these decisions are number sound or companyrect.

precedents.case_name: Greaves Cotton and Crompton Parkinson Ltd. v. Its Workmen
precedents.cited_proposition: support appellants' arguments on income-tax provision

precedents.citation: Bengal Chemical Pharmaceutical Works, Ltd. v. Their Workmen  3

anchor.surface_text: The last case to which our attention has been drawn by Mr. Viswanatha Sastri is the decision of the Labour Appellate Tribunal in Bengal Chemical Pharmaceutical Works, Ltd. v. Their Workmen  3 . This case decides that in providing for income-tax the tax payable by the companycern on its income earned in the year for which bonus is claimed must be ascertained.

precedents.case_name: Bengal Chemical Pharmaceutical Works Ltd. v. Their Workmen
precedents.cited_proposition: income-tax payable on income earned in the year for bonus, not actually paid (prior year tax)

justification_sets.label: Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support

outcome.relief_summary: The three civil appeals (Nos. 217, 218, 219 of 1956) fail on merits and are dismissed, upholding the Labour Appellate Tribunal's decisions on bonus award and review refusal.

anchor.surface_text: That is why, in the result, this subsequent Full Bench held that only normal depreciation including multiple shift depreciation, but not initial or additional depreciation, should rank as prior charge in applying the Full Bench formula as to the payment of bonus. If it cannot be disputed that in industrial adjudication it is not obligatory to adopt the very same procedure as prescribed by the Income-tax Act for ascertaining gross profits and then determining the amount of net surplus available, it is not easy to accept the appellants argument that in respect of depreciation alone industrial tribunals must necessarily and in every case follow the relevant provisions of the Income-tax Act.

That is why, in the result, this subsequent Full Bench held that only normal depreciation including multiple shift depreciation, but not initial or additional depreciation, should rank as prior charge in applying the Full Bench formula as to the payment of bonus. If it cannot be disputed that in industrial adjudication it is not obligatory to adopt the very same procedure as prescribed by the Income-tax Act for ascertaining gross profits and then determining the amount of net surplus available, it is not easy to accept the appellants argument that in respect of depreciation alone industrial tribunals must necessarily and in every case follow the relevant provisions of the Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: This Court has recently had occasion to consider the question about the applicability of the Code of Civil Procedure to the proceedings before the Labour Appellate Tribunal in Mills. Martin Burn Ltd. v. R. A. Banerjee Civil Appeal No. 92 of 1957. Section 91 and s. 10 of the Industrial Disputes Appellate Tribunal Act, 1950, as well as the relevant rules and orders framed under the Act were considered and it was held that the Code of Civil Procedure applies to the proceedings before the appellate tribunal with the result that the appellate tribunal can exercise its powers under O. 41, r. 21 as well as under s. 151 of the Code. It is true that in this case there was no occasion to consider the applicability of the provisions of O. 47 of the Code but that does not make any difference. If the Code of Civil Procedure applies to the proceedings before the Labour Appellate Tribunal, it is clear that the provisions of O. 47 would apply to these proceedings as much as s.151 of the Code or the provisions of O. 41. We must accordingly hold that the appellate tribunal erred in law in coming to the conclusion that it had no jurisdiction to review its own order under the provisions of O. 47 of the Code.

This Court has recently had occasion to consider the question about the applicability of the Code of Civil Procedure to the proceedings before the Labour Appellate Tribunal in Mills. Martin Burn Ltd. v. R. A. Banerjee Civil Appeal No. 92 of 1957. Section 91 and s. 10 of the Industrial Disputes Appellate Tribunal Act, 1950, as well as the relevant rules and orders framed under the Act were considered and it was held that the Code of Civil Procedure applies to the proceedings before the appellate tribunal with the result that the appellate tribunal can exercise its powers under O. 41, r. 21 as well as under s. 151 of the Code. It is true that in this case there was no occasion to consider the applicability of the provisions of O. 47 of the Code but that does not make any difference. If the Code of Civil Procedure applies to the proceedings before the Labour Appellate Tribunal, it is clear that the provisions of O. 47 would apply to these proceedings as much as s.151 of the Code or the provisions of O. 41. We must accordingly hold that the appellate tribunal erred in law in coming to the conclusion that it had no jurisdiction to review its own order under the provisions of O. 47 of the Code.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, satisfied that the grievance made by the appellants against the order passed by the appellate tribunal on the ground that it suffers from a mistake apparent on the face of the record is not well founded.

We are, therefore, satisfied that the grievance made by the appellants against the order passed by the appellate tribunal on the ground that it suffers from a mistake apparent on the face of the record is not well founded.
In the result, the appeals fail on the merits and must be dismissed with costs.
